title: FlpStop, a tool for conditional gene control in <italic>Drosophila</italic>
abstract: Manipulating gene function cell type-specifically is a common experimental goal in <italic>Drosophila</italic> research and has been central to studies of neural development, circuit computation, and behavior. However, current cell type-specific gene disruption techniques in flies often reduce gene activity incompletely or rely on cell division. Here we describe FlpStop, a generalizable tool for conditional gene disruption and rescue in post-mitotic cells. In proof-of-principle experiments, we manipulated <italic>apterous</italic>, a regulator of wing development. Next, we produced conditional null alleles of <italic>Glutamic acid decarboxylase 1</italic> (<italic>Gad1</italic>) and <italic>Resistant to dieldrin</italic> (<italic>Rdl</italic>), genes vital for GABAergic neurotransmission, as well as <italic>cacophony</italic> (<italic>cac</italic>) and <italic>paralytic</italic> (<italic>para</italic>), voltage-gated ion channels central to neuronal excitability. To demonstrate the utility of this approach, we manipulated <italic>cac</italic> in a specific visual interneuron type and discovered differential regulation of calcium signals across subcellular compartments. Thus, FlpStop will facilitate investigations into the interactions between genes, circuits, and computation.
